What is Bash?

  • Bash is a shell for the GNU operating system

What is a shell?

  • A shell is a macro processor that executes commands

Is Bash the only shell available?

  • No.
  • There are many many alternatives, such as sh, ksh, csh or zsh
  • However, bash is the default shell in GNU systems

Can I use bash only in GNU systems?

  • No.

entry.title: Course Introduction
entry.summary:
Instructor

  • Eunjeong (Lucy) Park
  • PhDc for data mining at Seoul National University
  • You can call me "Ms. Park"
    • Normally to professors, using "Dr." is a better idea
  • a.k.a., lucypark, echojuliett, e9t

Course logistics

  • Course objective: Pragmatic data mining application on real data
  • Work for the course
    • Class meets every Friday 14:00-18:00
    • Most classes will be consisted of two parts
      1. Lectures, tutorials or invited speeches
      2. Short presentations by each team/individual
  • Course website: http://lucypark.kr/courses/2015-ba
    • Lecture notes
    • Schedule/Announcements
  • For questions use the mailing list: 2015-ba@googlegroups.com
    • Anything you want to ask goes here
    • Using any language of your choice (ex: English, Korean, Java, ...)
  • Office hours
    • Right after every class
    • You are welcome to ask any kind of questions
    • You are also encouraged to book ahead, or your meeting may have to be deferred to another time

Grading

  • Assignments (20%): You will be given four graded assignments during the semester.
  • Mid-terms (20%): A mid-term quiz.
  • Finals (60%): A final exam and presentation.

Term Project

You will be conducting a term project throughout the semester. There will be four designated assigments according to the project, and one graded presentation at the end of the semester.

Advice on your projects

  • The best topics are the topics you are actually interested in
    • You should be able to "dogfood" your own analysis
  • Don't be afraid to shift the project's direction
    • However, shifting too much will give you less time for real work -- balance!
  • Feel free to use project results in your graduation project or paper
    • Grab two rabbits at once!
    • These projects have potential to become something in your portfolio
    • May be a plus when you get a job, or apply for grad school

Presenting project progress

  • Update your progress (max 10 minutes)
    1. Prepare printouts (for the whole class) or slides or whatever format that best conveys your work
      • Please share your materials at the forum before class
    2. Be brief yet clear
      • Note: Clarity wins brevity
    3. Take notes
      • Keep precise research progress and feedback notes

A good presentation contains the following: 1. What questions you had 1. What approach you chose to alleviate such questions 1. What results you achieved 1. What questions you further got and what you plan to do next 1. Tricks and tips you want to share with the class

Using the forum

How to ask good questions

  • Explicitly list versions of software being used (including packages and OSs)
  • Provide as much details as you can
  • However, remember "brevity and clarity"

What you'll need for this course

  • An OS of your choice (ex: Windows 7, Mac OS X, Ubuntu 14.04)
  • An editor or IDE of your choice

Other notices

  • You are welcome to bring electronic devices to class
    • Use them actively for more active discussions
    • You can even drift off, it's just your responsibilty
  • Never hesitate in asking questions
  • Excuses can be accepted in prior of an event, but never after
  • Extra credit will be given to those who rank in Kaggle, or submit their work to a conference or journal

Homework 0: Self introduction

Submit a CV and self-introduction paper in English or Korean (Due: 2015-03-12 23:59)

  1. CV
    • Please include your name, student ID, phone number, email address
    • No constraint on formats, but please try to avoid proprietary formats such as hwp, docx (cf. CVs and file extensions)
      • PDF or HTML
    • No page limits
    • Extra credit for those who include their LinkedIn URL
  2. Self-introduction paper
    • Please include the following:
      1. Your characteristics
      2. Why you're taking this course and what you expect from it
      3. What you wish to do in the future
    • No page limits (Though I don't think I will be reading after page three)

You are seniors! This is a great chance to practice writing and getting feedback on your CV (which you will definitely be sending to companies and/or schools in the near future)

  • Tips on writing a good CV
    • http://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/80/latex-template-for-resume-curriculum-vitae
  • Tips on writing a good self-introduction
    • Use positive words.
    • Divide an conquer!
      • Step 1. Focus only on the contents! (Using a basic text editor or plain paper might be a good idea)
      • Step 2. Do the formatting. Formatting matters. (ex: fonts, layouts, tenses, etc.)

entry.title: Business Analytics (Spring 2015)
entry.summary:
Welcome to Business Analytics class of 2015! Here you'll find all course materials, guides and schedules. In case you have questions, feel free to send an email to 2015-ba@googlegroups.com (or directly write a new topic at the forum below).

Data mining and analytical skills are at the heart of solving many important problems in our world. In this course, we aim to derive technology-based solutions to such problems, and develop strategical decision making abilities based on data.

Specifically, we discuss technologies, applications, practices, and skills for continuous iterative exploration and investigation of business performance with external data collected from diverse sources such as the Web, in order to gain insights and drive business planning. Topics include statistical and quantitative analysis, explanatory and predictive modeling, as well as text analytics with visualization. Students are required to present progress on their work during the semester, and are assessed by a set of assignments, quizzes and exams.

Note that this course is the second part of a two part sequence. We assume you have already taken Data Mining (ex: ITM522), the first part of the sequence, where methods and algorithms for mining data were discussed. This course is the latter part of the sequence, and will be more advanced and project-focused.

Prerequisites

  • Familiarity in data mining algorithms
  • Good knowledge with at least one programming language (ex: R, Python, Java, etc.)

What you will learn

  • Use algorithms to extract meaningful insight from large datasets
  • Understand the usage of data mining in a domain of interest
  • Develop analytical and data-based thinking

Grading

  • Assignments (20%): You will be given four graded assignments during the semester.
  • Mid-term Quiz (20%): A mid-term quiz.
  • Final Exam (60%): A final exam and presentation.
